Why Nancy Pelosi's Comments About Capitalism Disappointed Progressives The minority leader‚Äôs critics claim she sounded out of touch at a town hall Tuesday. 02/01/2017 06:49 pm ET Daniel Marans Reporter, Huffington Post 
Democrats are clamoring to harness the energy of millennial progressive activists, who mostly favored Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) in the presidential primary. 
But an exchange between a college student and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) at a CNN-hosted town hall on Tuesday night illustrates how challenging that can be in practice. 
Responding to a question about whether Democrats could adopt more progressive economic positions, Pelosi launched into an academic explanation of American capitalism that critics derided as tone-deaf in the current populist environment. 
Trevor Hill, a 20-year-old sophomore public policy major at New York University, first pointed to a Harvard poll from April showing that 51 percent of people aged 18 to 29 do not support capitalism. 
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not me asking you to make a radical statement about capitalism but I‚Äôm just telling you that my experience is the younger generation is moving left on economic issues,‚Äù Hill explained. 
‚ÄúBut I wonder if there‚Äôs anywhere you feel the Democrats could move farther left to a more populist message, the way the alt-right has sort of captured this populist strain on the right wing ‚Äï if you think we could make a more stark contrast to right-wing economics?‚Äù 
‚ÄúI thank you for your question. But I have to say, we‚Äôre capitalist ‚Äï and that‚Äôs just the way it is,‚Äù Pelosi responded with a chuckle. ‚ÄúHowever, we do think that capitalism is not necessarily meeting the needs with the income inequality that we have in our country.‚Äù 
The California Democrat went on to decry the departure of American capitalism from a ‚Äústakeholder‚Äù system where worker pay grew in tandem with productivity, and the current ‚Äúshareholder-driven‚Äù model that has depressed pay and produced record inequality. It was an analysis that would not have been out of place in a column by liberal economist Paul Krugman. 
But Pelosi‚Äôs efforts to defend capitalism suggested she interpreted Hill‚Äôs query as a request for Democrats to abandon the free market entirely. 
And she did not address the question of whether the Democratic Party has room to be more economically progressive, or otherwise present the party‚Äôs vision for confronting the inequality she described in such detail. 
Pelosi‚Äôs remarks, which you can watch above in full, immediately drew jeers from progressive critics on Twitter, some of whom turned Hill‚Äôs name into a hashtag. Pelosi lays out the problem (income inequality) that the young man raised but never offers a solution. https://t.co/7lvGkWgVPA ‚Äî Anthony De Rosa (@Anthony) February 1, 2017 This guy isn't even making a big ask of Pelosi, he's just asking for "contrast with right wing economics". Yet she casually dismisses him. ‚Äî Luke Savage (@LukewSavage) February 1, 2017 Does anyone know #TrevorHill 's Twitter handle? My campaign for congress would like to answer his question on air, since Nancy Pelosi did not pic.twitter.com/OFGy0FGy2v ‚Äî Brianna Wu (@Spacekatgal) February 1, 2017 @historyinflicks I've never seen her so animated & passionate about anything like she was issuing her Proclamation in Defense of Capitalism. ‚Äî Glenn Greenwald (@ggreenwald) February 1, 2017 #TrevorHill asked the question that we should ask all Dems. And if the answer resembles @NancyPelosi 's, they shouldn't have a job. ‚Äî Mr Impermanence üåπ (@mr_impermanence) February 1, 2017 hello congresswoman do you think maybe the democrats can try to suck a little less pelosi: absolutely not. eat shit everyone ‚Äî raandy (@randygdub) February 1, 2017 
Hill, for his part, had a more ambivalent reaction to Pelosi‚Äôs answer. 
‚ÄúI was actually surprised that she was so open about a lot of the flaws that she sees in the capitalist system ‚Äï at least, in her eyes a capitalist system that has arisen from an older, better system,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt expect that.‚Äù 
But Hill said he was also ‚Äúkind of disappointed‚Äù that Pelosi did not address whether the Democratic Party should adopt a more populist platform. ‚ÄúShe just completely ignored that question.‚Äù 
Hill, who is registered to vote in California, identifies as an ‚Äúindependent leftist‚Äù rather than a Democrat. He voted for Sanders in the primary and then Green Party nominee Jill Stein in the general election. 
‚ÄúAs a former Democrat, I had some stuff that I really did want to know about, like if they were going to make any effort to regain a lot of the voters they lost during the election cycle,‚Äù Hill said. 
Although his recent voting pattern might make it tempting to dismiss someone like Hill as a lost cause, his personal story is not that different from many disaffected working-class voters whose support Democrats are so eager to win back. Hill used to be an enthusiastic Democrat and supporter of President Barack Obama. But he grew ‚Äúdisillusioned‚Äù with Democrats, he said, when their rosy rhetoric clashed with the economic misery his family was experiencing. 
His parents declared bankruptcy three years ago after a drop in his father‚Äôs income as a construction contractor made it impossible for them to pay their bills. He can attend NYU thanks to a full scholarship he receives. 
The bankruptcy ‚Äúwas during the best years of the recovery when everyone was singing [Obama‚Äôs] praises and saying ‚Äòeverything‚Äôs doing so well, America‚Äôs back on track.‚Äô Meanwhile my parents were choosing between having the lights on and putting food on the table,‚Äù Hill recalled. ‚ÄúIt was almost insulting really to feel ignored like that. And I know so many people who have the same story.‚Äù She blew an opportunity to connect the Democratic Party not just with the Democratic base but with people questioning why they supported Trump. Nomiki Konst 
Nomiki Konst, a surrogate for Sanders during the primary who is now an investigative reporter for the Young Turks, is eager to make a place for people like Hill in the Democratic Party. She was quick to praise Pelosi‚Äôs famously progressive legislative record. 
‚ÄúI have been defensive of [Pelosi],‚Äù Konst said. ‚ÄúIn terms of what she does in Congress, she does it very well.‚Äù 
‚ÄúWith that being said, she proved herself to be completely out of touch with what‚Äôs happening last night,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúHis question was super thoughtful and she blew an opportunity to connect the Democratic Party not just with the Democratic base but with people questioning why they supported Trump.‚Äù 
Konst saw Pelosi‚Äôs response, which she characterized as ‚Äúpreachy,‚Äù as symptomatic of some Democratic leaders‚Äô condescending view of millennials. Pelosi may simply not be the person to reach that audience, but some Democrats must, according to Konst. 
Meanwhile, a radical left emboldened by the Democrats‚Äô failure to defeat Donald Trump viewed Tuesday‚Äôs town hall as more evidence that the Democratic Party is a limited vehicle for change. 
‚ÄúWe were very blessed that [Hill] did that‚Äù because of the flaws it exposed in many Democrats‚Äô message, said David Duhalde, deputy director of the Democratic Socialists of America. 
DSA, which mobilizes a broad range of progressives and occasionally endorses Democrats, has seen its dues-paying membership grow from 6,500 people last March to 15,000 people now. It has offered to waive Hill‚Äôs membership fee and invited him to attend a Brooklyn conference for students over President‚Äôs Day weekend. 
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre reaching out to everyone as much as possible to make sure that his kind of great actions, and really showing the differences that are going on, will be seen, because we expect hundreds of students to attend,‚Äù Duhalde concluded. ‚ÄúWe are looking for a real alternative to the stale messaging coming from liberal leaders.‚Äù
